characters: INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT/INT. YORKSHIRE COTTAGE. DUSK
EXT. 12 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. LADY WIGGIN'S HOUSE. DAY

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY ROAD. DAY, (1960)
dialogues.text: A country lane c. 1960 with MISS SHEPHERD at the wheel of van barrelling along, her face set and anxious. Distantly hear the sound of a police siren (or bell it would be in 1960). She pulls the van into a side road or clearing and waits, ducking behind the seat as she sees the police car pass the end of the road. MISS SHEPHERD rights herself, checks the side of the van. Wipes her hand on it. Blood. crosses herself. Then starts up the van and drives off th way she has come. As she turns the corner, we see that the police car has stopped at the end of the road. A solitary policeman, UNDERWOOD, gets out of the car and watches the van disapp ROLL TITLES over —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glamorous pianist in a décolleté evening gown (along th lines of Anne Todd in 'The Seventh Veil' c. 1947) playing some bravura piano concerto. As the titles end, so does the concerto, and we hear ALAN BENNETT in voice over and cut to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN BENNETT at his desk, writing.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The smell is sweet, with urine only a minor component, the prevalent odour suggesting the inside of someone's ear. Dank clothes are there too, wet wool and onions, which she eats raw, plus what for me has always been the essence of poverty, damp newspaper. The sound of the lavatory flushing. ALAN BENNETT looks towards the toilet door.  4/6 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 2.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd's multi-flavoured aroma is masked by a liberal application of various talcum powders, with Yardley's Lavender always a favourite, and currently it is this genteel fragrance that dominates, the second subject, as it were, in her odoriferous concerto. MISS SHEPHERD comes out of the lavatory, pulls down her skirt, and leaves through the front door. We see somethin the inside of the house and its contents, still at this d c. 1976, fairly uncluttered.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But as she goes the original theme returns, her own primary odour now triumphantly restated and left hanging in the house long after she has departed. Out of the window we see Miss Shepherd's van parked in th drive and MISS SHEPHERD herself rearranges some plastic b beneath the van. She is tall and though her changes of costume will not be described in detail, she is generally dressed in an assortment of coats and headscarves but wit variety of other hats superimposed on the headscarves. Ol raincoats figure, as do carpet slippers and skirts which often been lengthened by the simple process of sewing on additional strips of material. She is about sixty-five.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: (at the desk, speaks) Tell her. As he watches through the window, A.B. - his other self - comes out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. approaches the van. A.B. (at the van) Miss Shepherd. In future I would prefer it if you didn't use my lavatory. There are lavatories at the bottom of the High Street. Use those.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: They smell. I’m by nature a very clean person. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a testimonial for a Clean Room, awarded me some years ago, and do you know my aunt, herself spotless said I was the cleanest of my mother’s children, (A.B. gives up, and goes) particularly in the unseen places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. catches ALAN BENNETT'S eye as he passes the study do

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The writer is double. There is the self who does the writing and there is the self who does the living. And they talk. They argue. Writing is talking to one’s self, and I've been doing it all my life, and long before I first saw this house five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years earlier, possibly with a subtitle, though the unkempt nature of the house and a ‘For Sale’ sign indicat that this is earlier. House empty. No van. A.B. comes round the corner of Inverness Street into Gloucester Crescent, and then into the garden with an EST

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: Fifteen?

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: Number 10 fetched seventeen. A.B. looks discouraged. ESTATE AGENT (CONT’D) Come on. I thought you had a play on in the West End. These houses have got so much potential. Once you get rid of the junk. Well there you have it: Gloucester Crescent. Good street. On the up and up. A.B. and the ESTATE AGENT walk up Gloucester Crescent. Th street is alive with refurbishing activity. As he speaks workmen bring out a nice marble fireplace out of No. 63 a shove it in the skip, breaking it in the process. More workmen carry materials into another house.  10 11 12 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 4. ESTATE AGENT (CONT’D) Big motor, have you? Loads of room.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. STUDY. DAY 10
dialogues.text: A.B. carries boxes of books into the empty study. Through window we see two men unloading a table or desk from a removal van. The sign now says 'Sold'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. leaves the house A.B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van stalled nearby, opposite a Convent. From MISS SHEPHERD'S POV we see A.B., with a WHSmith bag, through t van windscreen which is grimy, with the dashboard hosting variety of objects like a half-eaten tin of baked beans, packet of biscuit also half-eaten, various tissues, packe of soap flakes etc. A.B. stops to look at a cross (with a painted crucified Christ). MISS SHEPHERD appears at his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You're not St John, are you? A.B. St John who?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: St John. The disciple whom Jesus loved. A.B. No. My name's Bennett.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Well, if you're not St John I need a push for the van. It's conked out, the battery possibly. I put some water in only it hasn't done the trick. A.B. Was it distilled water?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It was holy water so it doesn't matter if it was distilled or not. The oil is another possibility.  12b 13 14 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 5. A.B. That's not holy too?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Holy oil in a van? It would be far too expensive. I want pushing round the corner. EXT. CONVENT. DAY 12b A.B. starts to push. MISS SHEPHERD goes though her repert of hand signals: 'I am moving off .. I am turning left' . movements done with boneless grace and in textbook Highwa Code fashion. A.B. Are you wanting to go far?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Possibly. I'm in two minds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car passes. MISS SHEPHERD stops the van and crou down. MISS SHEPHERD emerges cautiously. A.B. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I need the other end. A.B. That's half a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I'm in dire need of assistance. I'm a sick woman, dying possibly, just looking for a last resting place, somewhere to lay my head. Do you know of anywhere? A.B. goes

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bye bye madam. Mind how you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. is back in the study, empty except for the desk and boxes of books piled high, which he has started to unpack  15 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 6.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A proper writer might welcome such an encounter as constituting experience. Me, I have to wait and mull it over.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: She saw you coming. A.B. She's old.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: You wouldn't get Harold Pinter pushing a van down the street. A.B. No. Unlike me. But then, I’m too busy not writing plays, and leading my mad, vigorous creative life.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. You live it. I write it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD'S POV inside the van driving slowly round t street, sussing it out. As she passes no. 23 her POV: A.B. outside with his bike, with RUFUS and PAULINE, neighbours living opposite.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Pretty house, not as big as ours, of course; but you're unattached. A.B. No. It's attached to the house behind.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: No, you. You're...single. Sickert once lived in the street, apparently; Dickens’ abandoned wife. Now it's the usual north London medley: advertising, journalism, TV, people like you - writers, 'artists'. Anything in the pipeline? A.B. Well, I've got a play on in the West End.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Of course you have. Dare one ask?  16 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 7. A.B. Thirteen five.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Oh my God! A.B. I know.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: And we're twice as big, so what does that make ours worth?

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Mind you, our new neighbour won't help the prices. Shot of the van now parked at the top of the street. A.B. Yes, we’ve met.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Last year it was Gloucester Avenue. Now it's our turn.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: She seems to have settled at 66. A.B. Will they mind?

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: I hope not. We like to think we’re a community. A.B. rides off on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What play has he got on?

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: We saw it. That domestic thing.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: (thinks, then shakes her head) Gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Plastic bags being hurled under the van by MISS SHEPHERD. Through the open window of No.42 we hear the so of children playing London's Burning on their recorders, this scene goes on, another small child arrives, lugging cello home. FIONA PERRY comes out of the house.  17 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 8.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (to Miss Shepherd) We thought you might like some pears. They’re from our garden in Suffolk.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Pears repeat on me. She goes on hurling bags.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Were you planning on staying long?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Not with that din going on. MISS SHEPHERD gets in the van, and closes the door. FIONA goes back into her garden where her husband is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I know what you’re thinking. Still, it’s nice to feel we're doing our bit for the homeless. GILES PERRY, her husband, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. showing a young ACTOR round. The house is nearly emp A.B. I'd like to keep it like this. Simple.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Monastic. A.B. Quite. (moving into the bedroom) This is my bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Nice. A.B. So do you like being in the play?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Love it. Love it. So English. Just what people want. Bed looks comfortable.. A.B. Well maybe you could come round and give me a hand with the decorating.  18 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 9.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Sure. My girlfriend’s a dab hand at the painting. The ACTOR looks out of the window and sees MISS SHEPHERD pushing her wheelie past. ACTOR (CONT’D) On hello darling. You look a character. A.B. Well yes this is Camden Town. During the course of the film the house should gradually up with stuff so that at the finish there's as much clutt (of a superior kind) as the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. gives sixpence to MISS SHEPHERD, who is sitting on t pavement which is covered with messages she has chalked u like 'St. Francis hurled money from him' and 'Say No to t Common Market'. There is also a pile of pamphlets, one of which A.B. take She is just chalking in some rudimentary birds.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Yes I’m here most days, I teach... and the pavement is my blackboard. I also sell pencils. A gentlemen came by the other day and said that the pencil he had bought from me was the best pencil on the market at the present time. A.B. (reading leaflet) You're against the Common Market, I see.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Me? Who said it was me? A.B. You’re not the writer?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Not necessarily. I'll go so far as to say this. They are anonymous. And they are a shilling. You’ve only given me sixpence.  20 21 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 10. A.B. (pointing to the pavement) It says there St Francis hurled money from him.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Yes, only he was a saint. He could afford to.

dialogues.speaker: PASSER-BY
dialogues.text: (coming out of the bank and tripping over her) Sodding beggars.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I am not a beggar. I am self- employed. And this gentleman is my neighbour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD is putting her bags back in the van.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Oh. On the move again? You didn’t stay long.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: No. Because it was non-stop music.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Lucy is doing her O levels.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It’s the noise levels I’m worried about. She prepares to move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUFUS and PAULINE in evening dress, with a picnic hamper blankets, about to get into a cab. They wave to A.B.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Sorry about all this. Glyndebourne.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: ‘Cosi'. A.B. Lucky you. Have fun. As the cab goes up the street we see MISS SHEPHERD in her van, doing her elaborate hand signals and slowly moving d the Crescent.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 11.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Oh, look out. Madam’s on the move.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: So whose turn will it be now? (To the cab driver.) Slow down.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch) We don’t want to miss the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Mrs Vaughan Williams?

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: No. The Birts.
Elaborate signing from MISS SHEPHERD that she is coming t halt.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. No. No. Darling, that's us.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Stop the cab. He runs back down the street.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry! You can't park here.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I've had guidance this is where it should go.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Guidance? Who from?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: The Virgin Mary. I spoke to her yesterday. She was outside the post office in Parkway.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: What does she know about parking?

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: (also having emerged from the cab) Rufus! Tell her, we're going to Glyndebourne.  22 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 12.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I need a ruler. I must measure the distance between the tyres and the kerb. One and a half inches is the ideal gap. I came across that in a Catholic motoring magazine under tips on Christian parking.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: This isn't Christian parking. It's a fucking liberty. They head back up towards the cab. They get back into the cab and drive off, some of this encounter having been seen by A.B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. calls over to the van, now directly opposite his hou A.B. You didn't stay long outside 66. MISS SHEPHERD comes over the road to A.B., worried.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Not with all that din. They're not musical, are they? A.B. Who?

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: No. Though they go to the opera. Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: What with all this to-do, I think I’m about to be taken short. Can I use your lavatory? She is already on her way into the house. A.B. No. The flush is on the blink.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I don't mind. She is in the house. We hear her calling ‘Where is it? Wh is it?’ before the door bangs and we see A.B.’s agonised face?  23 23b 24 25

dialogues.speaker: INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY
dialogues.text: 23 Later. The toilet flushes and MISS SHEPHERD comes out pas him saying nothing. Furious, A.B. calls after her. A.B. ‘Thank you?’ She ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. scrubs out the lavatory.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YORKSHIRE COTTAGE. DUSK
dialogues.text: 23b 24 A.B's mother's cottage, in a village in the Yorkshire dal Lights are on downstairs. We can see A.B's MAM through th window, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (On telephone) I’ve got a meeting at the BBC.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: What about? ; A.B. (V.0.) . It’s just something I’m writing.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: I thought you were coming up.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In a week or two.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT/INT. YORKSHIRE COTTAGE. DUSK
dialogues.text: 25 A.B. on the phone to his mother. ALAN BENNETT at the desk

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: I’m on my own. A.B. I know you’re on your own.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: We’re all on our own.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: Can I come down there for a bit? Is it a big house?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 14. A.B. Not really. You wouldn't like it. Too many stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: They have these chair lift things now. (Pause) Are you still there? A.B. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: The foot feller came today. A.B. Who? ALAN BENNETT begins to write this exchange down, sat at h writing desk.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: The foot feller. A.B. Do you mean the chiropodist?

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: You've written that down.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: I haven't (He has.)

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: I've given you some script. I’m just raw material. A.B. No, you're not. (Pause) Mam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. VAUGHAN WILLIAMS rides her bike down the Crescent. M SHEPHERD has her door open, having just got up. She is fanning herself with a fan she has picked up somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s the van. Gets very close.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 15.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: I imagine.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You're tall.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: My husband was tall. I’m Mrs. Vaughan Williams. I won’t shake hands. Gardening.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: The composer? Greensleeves?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Among other things. Why? Are you musical? I don’t even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It’s Miss Shepherd, but I wouldn't want it bandied about. I’m in an incognito position, possibly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Safe with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS talking to A.B. MISS SHEPHERD the background, sorting the plastic bags under the van.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Shepherd. Drove ambulances in the war, apparently. A.B. So where did she spring from?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: And a nun once. A.B. A nun?

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: In the convent up the street. Still, everybody's got something to hide. My brother in law's a policeman. That's Camden. People wash up here. Like me. She’d be a good subject. A.B. What for?  28 34 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 16.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: You. One of your little plays. (She goes off saying -) Remember! I planted the seed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN BENNETT is at the desk, his notebook open in front o him.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: No, no. I’m writing about Mam half the time as it is. One old lady’s enough. A.B. I live. You write. That's how it works.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Except you don't much. A.B. Don't what?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Live. "Put yourself into what you write." How? We're both so fucking tame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD is clambering into the van when LOIS approaches. In the van, a battered portable radio is tune Radio 4.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd. I'm Lois, the social worker.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I don't want the social worker. I'm about to listen to the repeat of Any Answers.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: I've brought you some clothes. You wrote asking for a coat.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Not during Any Answers. I'm a busy woman. I only asked for one coat.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: I brought three, in case you fancied a change.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 17.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Where am I supposed to put three coats? Besides, green isn't my colour. She throws the green coat out the van on to the ground. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT’D) Have you got a stick?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: The council have that in hand. It’s been precepted for.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Will it be long enough?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Yes. It's one of our special sticks.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I don't want a special stick. I want an ordinary stick. Only longer. Shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: If I should want to get in touch with you whom should I call? MISS SHEPHERD is closing the van doors.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You can try Mr Bennett at 23 only don't take any notice of what he says. He's a communist, possibly. A.B. Have you tried the people opposite, they’re nearer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. on doorstep of 23 Gloucester Crescent. A.B. Have you tried the people opposite, they’re nearer?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: They said they don't relate to her. You were the one she related to.  36

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: Is that what they said, ‘related to'?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: No. That's me. They said you were her pal. She was your girlfriend. A.B. Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Does she use your lavatory? A.B. Only in an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: That might give her squatter’s rights. We'd be much happier if she moved on. A.B. We?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Camden.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMDEN HIGH STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: 36 Later. MISS SHEPHERD watches TV though Curry's window: Ed Heath arriving in Downing Street 1970. A.B. arrives with her shopping. A.B. I've got everything - sherbet lemons, Cup-a-Soup, the miniature whisky.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: That's medicinal. They walk together up the High Street, MISS SHEPHERD push her child's push-chair. A.B. She seemed very understanding, the social worker.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Not understanding enough. I ask for a wheelchair and what does she get me? A walking stick. (and she looks at him meaningfully) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And she says I don’t get an allowance unless I get an address. A.B. ‘The Van, Gloucester Crescent’ - isn’t that an address?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: No it needs to be a house. A residence. Still, I may be going away soon, possibly. A.B. How long for?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Broadstairs, possibly. A.B. Why Broadstairs? Have you family there?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: No. NO. A.B. Have you got any family?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I just need the air.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 36a EXT. INVERNESS STREET MARKET. DAY 36a

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I saw a snake this afternoon. It was coming up Parkway. It was a long grey snake. It was a boa constrictor, possibly. A.B. No...

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It looked poisonous. It was keeping close to the wall. I have a feeling it may have been heading for the van. A.B. No, Miss Shepherd...

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I thought I’d better warn you just to be on the safe side. I’ve had some close shaves with snakes.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 20. A.B. Listen to me Miss Shepherd. There are no boa constrictors in Camden Town.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Are you calling me a liar? I know a boa constrictor when I see one. Pitying smile from A.B. A street trader calls over.

dialogues.speaker: STREET TRADER
dialogues.text: All right, my love? You’re looking especially lovely today, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Don’t sweetheart me. I’m a sick woman. Dying possibly.

dialogues.speaker: STREET TRADER
dialogues.text: Well chin up love, we all got to go some time. Smells like you already have.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I do not believe in the snake, still less that it was en route for the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PERRY CHILDREN playing in their garden. Piercing scre Fiona comes up.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD, (SAM)
dialogues.text: Mummy! Mummy! There’s a snake!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Only next day I find there has been a break in at the local pet shop, so there may have been a snake on the run... A boa constrictor slithers through the flower bed.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So of course I feel guilty. The CHILDREN and FIONA run into the house shouting ‘A sna A snake!’

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 37b 39 40 40a 4l 43 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 21. INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY. 37b Alan Bennett sits at his desk, writing.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A real writer would have asked her about her close shaves with snakes. Only she seems to have cleared off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus pulls in. MISS SHEPHERD gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICEMAN has stopped MISS SHEPHERD, who is in her usua long skirt etc.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: A nightie? This isn’t a night dress. This style can’t have got to Broadstairs yet. And I know the law. You can’t be arrested for wearing a nightie.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: What’re you doing in Broadstairs?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I am minding my own business! EXT. BROADSTAIRS RESIDENTIAL ROAD. DAY. 40a MISS SHEPHERD is on her way up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A suburban housing estate of modest bungalows, backing on fields. MISS SHEPHERD approaches the end bungalow warily. She rin the bell. A solid, respectable man (MR FAIRCHILD) opens t door. He looks anxiously over his shoulder, shuts the doo behind him, and takes MISS SHEPHERD down the side of the house towards the garden shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAM is at the back-door.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: Alan! Come out here.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 22. A.B. (inside) What for?

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: There's some massive birds on the wall. A.B. There never are. There's nothing on the wall. You're imagining things.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: There are. A.B. comes to the door. There are four peacocks on the ga wall.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And there were, lined up on the garden wall, four peacocks from the Hall. So, boa constrictors in the street, peacocks on the wall, it seems that both at the northern and southern gates of my life stands a deluded woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. is back from Yorkshire. ALAN BENNETT is at the desk. A.B. Except you just said they aren't.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Aren't what? A.B. Deluded.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Well, not in this particular instance. A.B. And they're not the same Alan, Mam and Miss Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: No, Alan, they are not. But they are both old ladies. That appears to be my niche, apparently. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And whereas my contemporaries lovingly chronicle their first tentative investigations of the opposite sex, or their adventures in the world of journalism, I'm stuck with old ladies. He throws his notebook at A.B.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right - I am keeping a sodding notebook, but only on the off- chance. She’s not a project. She’s not in the pipeline. I don’t want to write about her. She’s just something that's happening. A.B. So what do you want to write about?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: I want to write about spies. A.B. Spies?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: There you are, you see. You think that's barmy. Spies. Russia. I can't always be writing about the North. (mimicking himself) 'I was born and brought up in Leeds where my father was a butcher, and as a boy I would often go out on the bike with the orders.' It's not Proust. It's not even J.B. Priestley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. in bathroom brushing his teeth watches: PAULINE take delivery of a carpet or other upmarket item.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The houses in the crescent were built as villas for the Victorian middle class and their basements are now being enlarged by couples who are liberal in outlook but not easy with their new found prosperity. Meanwhile, RUFUS leaves home for work with his briefcase passes MISS SHEPHERD who is struggling to unscrew a bottl top.  47 46 30 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 24.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Guilt, in a word, which means that in varying degrees they tolerate Miss Shepherd, their consciences absolved by her presence. He stops and with an ill grace turns back and puts his ha out for the bottle. He unscrews it and hands it back. All done slightly furtively lest anyone observe his good turn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow. The two youngest PERRY CHILDREN come with FIONA and reluctant GILES and knock on the van door. They have Christmas presents for MISS SHEPHERD.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY FAMILY
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas! She takes the presents.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Shut the door. Shut the door! I'ma busy woman. They close the van door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE approaches the van with a plate of leftovers, mouthing "creme briilée". MISS SHEPHERD takes it gracelessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. and an INTERVIEWER (American) sit at the kitchen tab with a tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: What was your first play about? A.B. Public school - which, more accurately, is what you Americans call private school.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: But you didn't go to public school. A.B. No, but I read about it.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 25.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: And what was your next play about? A.B. Sex. I read about that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PERRY CHILDREN are giving a concert on the pavement, cap for contributions. MISS SHEPHERD strides up the stree

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop it! Stop it this minute! Stop it! The children flee. GILES comes out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Do you have a problem?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: They were making a noise.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: They're children.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I am a sick woman.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: You certainly are. A car beeps its horn to get MISS SHEPHERD out of the road

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD ringing the bell. A.B. opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett. I've worked out a way of getting on the wireless. A.B. What?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I want to do one of those phone-in programmes. It's something someone like you could get put on ina jiffy. She pushes past him and goes into the study. A.B. gets in front of her and manages to get some paper on the seat be she sits down. (There is a TV in the corner of the study.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 26. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT’D) I could be called the Lady Behind the Curtain. Or A Woman of Britain, you see. You could take a nom de plume view of it. I see the curtain as being here, possibly. Some greeny material would do. A.B. I thought this was a phone-in.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Well? A.B. It's the radio. There's no need for a curtain at all.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Yes, well we can iron out these hiccups when the time comes. And if I come in I could catch up with some civilisation. A.B. Civilisation, what you mean the television?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Wild life. Famines. Sheep dog trials, possibly. I watch it in Curry’s window but it’s not ideal. A look between A.B. And ALAN BENNETT, who is at the desk. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT ’D) Je crois que vous passez les vacances en France. A.B. Yes. Er, oui.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: J'ai 6tudié en France il y a trente- cing ans. A.B. Avant la guerre?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: What guerre? A.B. La guerre mondiale numéro deux.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Oui. La deuxieme guerre mondiale.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 27. A.B. Qu'est ce que vous étudiez?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I was studying incognito 4 Paris. A.B. But what? What were you studying?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Music. The pianoforte, possibly. Have you got an old pan scrub? I'm thinking of painting the van. One of those little mop things they use to wash dishes with would do. She heads off down the corridor. A.B. How about a brush?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I've got a brush. It’s just for the first coat.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: OK, she’s been a nun. Only now it turns out she’s been a musician besides, and seemingly with fluent French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. MISS SHEPHERD is painting the van.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She's certainly no painter. Because today, rain notwithstanding, she moves slowly round her mobile home, thoughtfully touching up the rust patches, with crushed mimosa always a favourite shade. FIONA passes with a CHILD.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: She's using the wrong paint. Cars have special paint.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (viciously) Not this one. It’s Catholic paint. The CHILD is dragged away.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 28. They pass Crescent.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: And she smells.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: That's because she's poor. You'd smell if we were poor. MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS on the corner of Gloucester MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS stands next to A.B.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: (looking at the van) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Telling me about paint. I was in the infants' school. I won a prize for painting. A.B. But it's all lumps. You've got to mix it.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I have mixed it, only I've got some Madeira cake in it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Cake or no cake, all Miss Shepherd's vehicles ended up looking as if they'd been given a coat of badly made custard or plastered with scrambled eggs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Divine!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Still, there were few occasions on which one saw her genuinely happy and one of these was when she was putting paint on.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN-WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Jackson Pollock himself could not have done it better. Even with a pan scrub. An altercation across the street. An official is trying t post a removal order on the windscreen. A.B. looks up the crescent where council workers are pain yellow lines. A.B. Yellow lines.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 29.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Sorry? A.B. Parking restrictions.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Oh what a bore. A.B. She'll be illegally parked. She'll have to move on. MISS SHEPHERD is crossing the road with a removal order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. studies the form MISS SHEPHERD has brought over. A.B. It's a removal order.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I know it's a removal order. A.B. It means you'll have to drive on somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: But I'm disabled. I don't always use a walking stick and that pulls the wool over people's eyes. But I am a bona fide resident of Camden and I had rheumatic fever as a child. And mumps. A.B. I still think you'll have to move on. Go somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Well it won’t move. There’s not enough juice. A.B. Well I’1ll get you some up the road.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I don’t like their petrol. It could go, it just needs a bit of coaxing. What I'm worried about particularly are the wheels. They're under divine protection. If I do get this other vehicle I'd like the wheels transferred.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 30. A.B. What other vehicle?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: They may be miraculous, the tyres. They've only had to be pumped up once since 1964. A.B. What ‘other vehicle'?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: They only cost me a fiver. A.B. Miss Shepherd, you said about another vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: A van. A.B. Another van?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: A newer model. A titled Catholic lady says she may get me one as an act of charity. It's Lady Wiggin only she'd prefer to remain anonymous. A.B. I bet she would. So why don’t you park it outside her house?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 12 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. LADY WIGGIN'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: A.B. at Lady Wiggin’s front door.

dialogues.speaker: LADY WIGGIN
dialogues.text: It's out of the question. A.B. There’s plenty of room.

dialogues.speaker: LADY WIGGIN
dialogues.text: I have neighbours. A.B. So have I.

dialogues.speaker: LADY WIGGIN
dialogues.text: So should I not buy her another van?  56 59 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 31. A.B. (under his breath ) Please your fucking self.

dialogues.speaker: LADY WIGGIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. returning to the house. MISS SHEPHERD calls him over

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett...The ideal solution would be off-street parking. You know a driveway, possibly. A.B. So what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Play it by ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man in his mid sixties (UNDERWOOD), tall and sinister, approaches the van.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: Lady. (tapping lightly on the side of the van.) Are you there. Her side window is open a little and he slips his fingers inside. UNDERWOOD (CONT’D) Is this a bad moment? Have you got something for me? MISS SHEPHERD (unseen) bangs his fingers with a hammer or brick. UNDERWOOD (CONT’D) You bad bitch! You dirty lying bitch! He gives the van a great bang. A.B. opens the bathroom wi and calls across the road. A.B. Can I help you?  61 62 60 63 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 32.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: Good evening to you, sir. Finding myself in the vicinity, I am taking this opportunity to pay my compliments to Margaret. A.B. Margaret?

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: An old friend from way back. I've been out of the game for a while...you know how it is. A.B. You mean Miss Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: Shepherd, is it? Very good. A.B. She'll be asleep

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: Of course. I will bid you good night, sir. I will call again when my schedule permits. A.B. goes inside. UNDERWOOD lingers, and taps lightly on van. Two £20 notes are slid through the window. He taps again. Then another £20 note. UNDERWOOD (CONT’D) Thank you..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD being shaken around - a fairly frightening scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. looks out of the window and sees a commotion outside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A workman's van, with two young men in their twenties, wh get either side of the van and start shaking it and shout at MISS SHEPHERD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B., comes out as - jeering - the two guys drive off.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 33. A.B. Approaches the back of the van. A.B. Miss Shepherd. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd. Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (from within the van) I think so. What was it about? It wasn't the police, was it? A.B. No. They were louts. But if you choose to live like this it’s what you must expect.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I didn't choose. I was chosen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. is still in his dressing gown. A.B. Well that settles it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: You think? A.B. I can't always be looking out for her. I'm not her keeper. I mean, what happens to work? I think she should either go...or...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Or what? A.B. Or bring the van into the drive where we can forget about her. Actually, that's why some men marry...so they don't have to think any more about their wives.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: That's not bad. (He is writing it down)  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 34. A.B. Yes. Except it's Proust. And it'll only be for a few months until she decides where she's going. It'll be easier. But it's not kindness.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: No. (He reads from one of his notebooks ) ‘Good nature, or what is often considered as such, is the most selfish of all virtues: it is nine times out of ten mere indolence of disposition.' A.B. That's not you?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Hazlitt. And it's will. Pure will. She's known what she's wanted all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD is in the confessional with someone on the outside waiting his turn.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: The soul in question did confess, though in guarded terms, in Rome, in Holy Year, though I'm not sure the priest understood English. Do I look like a joy rider?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (patiently) My child. You have already been given absolution for this particular sin. I have given you it myself on several occasions. Have faith. Absolution is not like a bus pass. It does not run out. We see MISS SHEPHERD come out of the box as the next pers take her place and recoils.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (from behind the grille) There is air freshener behind the virgin.  65

dialogues.speaker: LADY IN THE VAN
dialogues.text: The man picks up a can of air freshener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dinner party in progress: the neighbours and Donald, a young actor, discuss A.B. who is currently not in the roo A silence.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: He's a saint. Ralph was the same. Some people are just kind.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Kind? This is London, Ursula. Nobody is kind.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: And now the old cow's got a foot in the door. He’s a fool.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Who else would do it?

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Well, we might... it’s just the girls...

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: I'm just an unemployed actor and I don't know the lady but can I ask something? What makes her Alan's problem?

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Darling. She is a human being.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Only just.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (to Donald) Changing the subject. When are we going to find Alan a girl? Silence. GILES rolls his eyes. FIONA tries again.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Josephine's pregnant again.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Oh no! Actually, I'm just trying to think who Josephine is.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: The hamster.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 36. A.B. returns carrying a fresh bottle of wine. A.B. Here we are.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: We were just saying how grateful she'll be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the van.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Put the van in your drive? That hadn’t occurred to me. I don't know. It might not be convenient. A.B. No. I've thought it over. Believe me, Miss Shepherd. It's all right. Just till you sort yourself out.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Not convenient for you. Convenient for me. You're not doing me a favour, you know. I have got other fish to fry. A man on the pavement told me if I went south of the river I'd be welcomed with open arms. A.B. watches her as she goes back to the van and starts t sort through her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was about to do her a good turn but, as ever, it was not without thoughts of strangulation. She would come into the garden, yes...but only as favour to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD walks round the old van for the last time. the broken windscreen she paints a cross. Her belongings been piled on the pavement outside No. 23. We see the council truck towing away the now empty van as new (though second-hand) van driven by MISS SHEPHERD with usual battery of hand signals comes down the Crescent. ALAN BENNETT watches from the study window. The neighbour watch from the street. Van being slowly driven into drive, comes to a stop (almo  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 37. A.B. Have you put on the handbrake?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I am about to do so.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Whereupon she applies the handbrake with such determination that, like Excalibur, it can never afterwards be released.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. STUDY. NIGHT 69
dialogues.text: A.B. coming into the study, and going to the living room window. Behind him, a young man comes in, pulling on a sh or T-shirt. He has a small overnight bag. A.B.'s POV of t van, MISS SHEPHERD inside praying, her paraffin light on.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now she is on the premises, I sometimes get a glimpse of Miss Shepherd praying and it is seldom a tranquil or a meditative process, the fervour of her intercessions rocking her to and fro. What is it she’s wanting forgiveness for? I used to pray myself when I was young. But never like this. I'd never done anything. But what has she done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the van, MISS SHEPHERD prays, a reproduction Assumption of the Virgin among her possessions.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: O Virgo Fidelis, first leader of all creatures, intercede on my behalf. I hunger and thirst for the fulfilment of a just era and utterly trust in possible light received.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. turns back to the young man on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Who’s the old bat? A.B. Oh, she’s...a friend.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: A friend? A.B. Someone I know.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Weird. A.B. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Actually I think I better be off. A.B. Yeah? You don't want to stay for coffee or anything?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Nah.

72 From Miss Shepherd's POV we see A.B. saying goodbye to th YOUNG MAN leaving. The YOUNG MAN waves at the gate. A.B. Is about to go back inside when MISS SHEPHERD’S hand comes through the window of the van.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett. That young man. Did he have an earring? A.B. He did.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You want to be careful.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: MAM and A.B. having tea, preparing to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: She'll be wanting to move in next.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0)
dialogues.text: Said my mother, who has been in London on a state visit.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me she was in the drive?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 75  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 39. A.B. I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: I got a whiff of her when I first came. A right nasty bad dishcloth smell. Well, she's in the garden. Next it'll be the house. What will folks think? A.B. This is London. Nobody thinks anything.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: It's with her being a nun, not having got off. They get thwarted. An educated woman and living like that. Mind you, you're going down the same road. A.B. Me?

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: No cloth on the table. No holder for the toilet roll. Given time I could have this place spotless. A.B. You've got a home. You wouldn't want to live here. MAM looks at A.B. It is plain she would like to do just t

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT, STAIRS/HALL. DAY 76
dialogues.text: They are climbing the stairs to the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: Where does she go to the lav? A.B. It's something to do with plastic bags.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: What sort of plastic bags? A.B. Stout ones, I hope. You’ve not met her, do you want to?

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: No. With her being educated I wouldn't know what to say.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 40. A.B. opening the door, the van visible in the doorway. A waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give us a kiss. When will you be coming up next? A.B. Soon.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: The thing is, I keep seeing a car in the car park. A.B. That's slightly to be expected, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: At night. Watching. A.B. Are you taking your tablets?

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: When I remember. She looks out at the van, and MISS SHEPHERD going about h business.

dialogues.speaker: MAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She should be in a home. Where does she go to the lav? A.B. I told you.

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: Looked after. A place where they'll wash her and make her presentable. I'm surprised they let her roam the streets. Mam walks to the back of the van where MISS SHEPHERD is sitting.

dialogues.speaker: MAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good morning. No response from Miss Shepard.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It’s like a fairy story. A Parable, in which the guilty is gulled in to devising a sentence for someone innocent only to find it is their own doom they have pronounced. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78a 78b 81 82 98 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 4l.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because my mother is much closer to being put in a home than Miss Shepherd Mam gets into the taxi. A.B. (to Mam) You got your purse?

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: Yes...I do miss your Dad. Give us a kiss. I asked our Gordon when he was a pilot did he go behind the clouds? A.B. And did he?

dialogues.speaker: MAM
dialogues.text: I can’t remember. He's a love, though. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY 78a MISS SHEPHERD paints the new van yellow. EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY 78b Later, she festoons the van with Union Jacks and other si jubilee paraphernalia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAM arrives at the front door with her shopping, alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Jehovah's Witnesses come up the drive and ring the fr door bell. A.B. comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JEHOVAH'S WITNESS
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. Does Jesus Christ dwell in this house? A.B. No. Try the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD at Curry's window watching Mrs Thatcher on  80 86 90 104 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd arrives home with an old TV in her push cha Later: A.B. running an electric cable from the house to t van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. watches as another young man leaves the house. The y man looks into the van where MISS SHEPHERD is watching ne coverage of the Falklands War. She sees him peering in.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (in the van) Clear off, you nosey blighter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come round the corner of Inverness Street and reach 23. MISS SHEPHERD goes towards the van.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett. A.B. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: These men. Who come late at night. I know what they are. A.B. (under his breath) Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: They're communists. Else why would they come at night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD in the van watching television. UNDERWOOD comes into the drive and taps on the van.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: (calling, menacingly) I like the new vehicle. Not a mark on it. (giving the van a great bang) Not a bloody scratch. What's your name now, Margaret?  Pause. THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 43.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (from van) My name's Mary. Go away.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: Mary is it now? Mary what?

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary what? He gives a great bang on the side of the van.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I'll call the police. UNDERWOOD pulls the van door open. She is cowering inside

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: Call the police? I don't think you will, you two-faced pisshole. Because calling the police is just what you didn't do. Apropos of which I think another contribution is due. Front door opens and A.B. comes out Beat. A.B. Can I help you? What's all this din?

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: No din, sir. Margaret and I were just taking a stroll down memory lane.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Don't Margaret me. That name is buried to sin. A.B. You came before.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: Of course, this isn't the van, is it? A.B. She had another one.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: That is kind of you. A homeless woman. A thankless soul and not over-salubrious. Goodbye Margaret.  105

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: I thought you said your name was Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It is. A.B. Why does he call you Margaret?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: He's taken too much to drink, on an empty stomach, possibly. A.B. It is your name: Mary Shepherd?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Subject to the Roman Catholic Church in her rights and to amendment, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s obviously not her name, and though it's long enough since she drove the van into the garden, I’m still too polite to ask who she is; let alone what this fellow wants who materialises at regular intervals and comes braying on the side of the van. Music has something to do with it..

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT, STUDY. NIGHT 105
dialogues.text: ALAN BENNETT at the desk. Both looking out towards the va The doors at the back are still open.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But is it just the noise, or music itself? A.B. puts some music on. Through the window they watch MISS SHEPHERD come out of t van and hurry to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (shouting) I can hear the music. I can hear it. Why must you play that? I can hear it! A.B. goes to the door.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD at the door. The music still playing. A.B. How can you dislike music? You used to play the piano.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: How do you know that? A.B. You told me.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I didn't say I didn't like it. I don't want to hear it, that's all. A.B. returns to the study.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Should she speak now? Should she explain? A.B. She never lets on. Never explains.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Well maybe she should.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I was once left alone in a room in the convent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see YOUNG MISS SHEPHERD, a novice.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They didn’t leave novices alone normally. And there was a piano there. I tried it and it was open. YOUNG MISS SHEPHERD starts to play. An OLD NUN comes in quietly.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It needed tuning and some of the notes were dead but it sounded more beautiful to me than any of the pianos I'd ever played. Then suddenly the mistress of the novices came in .. crept in possibly, because I didn’t hear her. She said: MISTRESS slams the piano cover.  108 109 114 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 46.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: That was what God wanted. And that I'd been told before. I said - Couldn't I just play some hymns for us to sing to? She said that was arguing, and I’d never make a nun if I argued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Old Peoples Home overlooking the sea at Weston Super M A.B. arrives in a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. sitting beside his MOTHER, on a bench in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So with painful symmetry my mother ends up in a home in Western Super Mare, while her derelict counterpart now resides in my garden. Putting my mother in a home I see as some sort of failure. And giving the other a home, that's a failure too.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. BATHROOM. DAY 114
dialogues.text: A.B. is upstairs. There is a distant sound getting nearer the time. Suddenly (and possibly with a bang) we see thro the window a three-wheeler Robin Reliant draw up. A.B. Oh Jesus. She's got herself a three wheeler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. walking round the Reliant now parked outside the hou ALAN BENNETT watching from the window. A.B. Where will you park it?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: In the residents' parking. A.B. You haven't got a permit.  Pause. Pause. Pause. THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 47.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I have. I got one yesterday. A.B. You never told me.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You'd only have raised objections if I had. A.B. Have you insured it?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I don't need insuring. It's like the van. I'm insured in heaven. A.B. So who pays if you have an accident? The Pope?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I shan't have an accident. A.B. What if you run into something?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I shan't run into anything. I'm an experienced driver. I drove ambulances in the blackout. A.B. What if someone runs into you?

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd. What if someone runs into you?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (fiercely ) You have no business saying that.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why do you say that? No one is going to run into me.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where's the key? A.B. What key?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 48.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: The car key. I put it down. A.B. I haven't got it.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You have. You've taken it. A.B. I have not.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You're lying. You don't want me to have the car so you've taken the key. A.B. Don't shout.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I have to shout because of your ignorance. People coming and going all hours of the day and night, I'd be better off in a ditch. Give me the key. A.B. I haven't got your sodding key. What's that round your neck? This. This. (He pushes her and she falls against the car.) The key. The sodding key. MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS comes past.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Having fun? A.B. (Beat) Shouldn’t you say sorry?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I’ve no time for sorry. Sorry is for God. A.B. and MISS SHEPHERD slowly recover, he watching her retreat into the van. ALAN BENNETT is at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This was the only time I ever touched her. It was not because she was calling me a liar, but because she seemed mad. It was my mother.

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: (calling through the study window to ALAN BENNETT) It's always Mam you compare her with. They are not the same. I don't like them even sharing the same sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. watching at the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These days it’s almost as if we’re married. MISS SHEPHERD is painting the Reliant.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘How’s your old lady?’, they say. Which is what people call a wife: your Old Lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. sitting in the stalls during a technical rehearsal w the director of his new play.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: How’s your old lady? A.B. She's still there. I'm still here.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Your mother died, didn't she? A.B. No. She's still here too. She was in hospital, but now she's ina home. Except she's not all there, you know. She's not anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Should we make that plain in the play? A.B. No. That's classified information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. watching at the window. MISS SHEPHERD is painting th Reliant.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Years ago Mam wanted Miss Shepherd put in a home, but she's still on the loose. Of course, whether she's all there or not is anyone's guess. She turns towards him and calls through the window. She i splattered with yellow paint.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett. I don't like the three- wheeler standing in the street. If you pushed the van in front of your window I could get the Reliant in there on the drive. There's tons of room. A.B. So I have the van and the Reliant?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I've had guidance that's where it should be. In terms of vandals. A.B. Guidance from whom?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I'm not at liberty to speak. I think I may contact my new social worker. A.B. What for? You always say you don't want the social worker.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (Returns to painting the Reliant) I've had guidance she might help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. now with the new social worker, MISS BRISCOE. A.B. I don’t want a used car lot.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Mary says...  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 51. A.B. Mary who?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Mary, your Lady in the Van. Didn't you know her name was Mary? A.B. I suppose I did. I always call her Miss Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: We all have names. Perhaps if you called her by her name and she called you by yours? Alan, Mary...You never know, it might be easier to talk things through. A.B. Through? There is no through. How do you talk things through with someone who has conversations with the Virgin Mary? You talk things through with Isaiah Berlin, maybe, who in comparison with Miss Shepherd is a man of few words, but you do not talk things through with her because you don't get through.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Alan. I'm getting a bit of hostility here. I realise for you this may be a steep learning curve... A.B. No. It is not a steep learning curve. I have never been on a so called learning curve. I’m about as likely to be found on a learning curve as I am on the ski slopes at Zermatt. And besides, her name isn't Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Oh? A.B. Some people seem to think it's Margaret. And it isn't even Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: I have her down as Mary. A.B. Yes, and you presumably have her down as a rational human being.  125 125a 119a 125b 126 127 128 130 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Reliant pulls up and parks on the front. MISS SHEPHER gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. comes out with some rubbish. He sees a small brown t on the side of the bin. EXT. BROADSTAIRS. DAY 125a Later: MISS SHEPHERD on the beach eating chips from newspaper. EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY 119a A.B. has plastic bags over his hands as he begins to remo the turd from the bin. EXT. BROADSTAIRS. DAY 125b Then: she sits on a children's carousel, as it revolves carrying her and two or three small children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD is served with a large ice cream sundae. EXT. CHURCH HALL, ON A ROAD NEAR THE SEAFRONT. DAY -— 127 A sign saying 'SENIOR CITIZENS CLUB. TEA, COFFEE AND CAKE ALL WELCOME’ MISS SHEPHERD goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gathering of pensioners. A young woman is about to play piano. MISS SHEPHERD is at the back helping herself to tea and biscuits. She hasn't noticed the pianist. Then the woman plays - Chopin, say. MISS SHEPHERD is about to flee, hesitates, then stays and listens, transported.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Reliant Robin slide into view and park not far from the end bungalow, and wait.  131 124 129 132 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 53. A woman (EDITH) comes out with a shopping bag. MISS SHEPH crouches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see MISS SHEPHERD'S slippered feet as she is crammed i a corner. The door opens. The solid, respectable man comes in, not looking at MISS SHEPHERD at first.

dialogues.speaker: MR FAIRCHILD
dialogues.text: Hello, Margaret. He looks at her warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Reliant on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD at the scene of the crash. She kneels, praying for forgiveness, as a car beeps its h behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Reliant is back, now parked a little way up the Cresc A.B. with his bike trying to look into the van when RUFUS PAULINE appear.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: What’s happened to Stirling Moss?.. I haven’t seen her at the wheel recently. A.B. Taking a well-earned break, I imagine. The Dordogne possibly.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Pauline. A.B. Her car's back. But I haven't seen her around for a bit. I wonder if she's alright.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 54.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Am I right in thinking that large many-contoured stain at the back of her frock denotes incontinence? A.B. Well, I don't think it's a fashion statement.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Oh, darling. What you must be hoping is that one of these days she'll just slip away.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Don't you believe it. That's what happens in plays. In life going downhill is an uphill job.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: How's your mother? A.B. Same. Sits. Smiles. Sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Are you all right? A.B. Me? Yes, why? Just going to the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Not upset about your play? A.B. No.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: I read a good review the other day. A.B. I was told they were all good.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Oh, they are, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: We enjoyed it - though I hadn't realised it was just going to be you and nobody else. A.B. Well, yes. It's a monologue.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Yes I suppose. I'm just amazed how you remember it all.  133 134 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 55.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: The review I saw was particularly perceptive about you. A.B. Really? Saying what?

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: That you couldn't make your mind up. A.B. About what?

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Anything really. It meant in a good way. A.B. Thanks. A.B. cycles off.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Actually I couldn't make it out at all. What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Him as usual. Not coming clean.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The National Theatre seen from Waterloo Bridge. On the electronic billboard: TALKING HEADS BY ALAN BENNETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scene from 'A Chip in the Sugar'.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (AS GRAHAM)
dialogues.text: «+. When I came down again she's still sat there with her hat and coat on. She said “Graham. My one aim in life is for you to be happy. If I thought that by dying it would make you happy, I would.” I said, “Mam, your dying wouldn't make me happy. In fact the reverse. It would make me unhappy. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 135 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 56.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (AS GRAHAM)
dialogues.text: Anyway, Mam, you're not going to die.” She said, “No. I'm not going to die. I'm going to get married. And the honeymoon is in Tenerife. Have one of your tablets.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. cycles down Gloucester Crescent

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So for the umpteenth time I bike back from the theatre where I've been talking about my mother. Though at least I know where my mother is. A.B. taps on the van window. A.B. Miss Shepherd. Miss Shepherd. (no answer) I don't like it. ALAN BENNETT has come to the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: So look in. A.B. No.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Are you scared? A.B. No.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Not of the body. You're scared this may be the end of the story and now I'm going to have to write it. Still, now she's gone I can make it up. Narrative freedom. Whoopee! A.B. (tapping on van.) Miss Shepherd. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Go on...  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 57. A.B. very nervously opens the back door of the van. MISS SHEPHERD appears from further up the Crescent.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Both ALAN BENNETTS react, startled.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Looking at my things? A.B. I thought you might be ill. Dead.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Dead? Me? A.B. I was concerned.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You were nosy. A.B. I hadn't seen you. I’m sorry. A.B. beats a retreat to the house, pursued by MISS SHEPHE

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I'm not dead. You'll know when I'm dead. A.B. I'm sorry. He goes into the house and shuts the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Dead! Me! I shan't die in a hurry, I can tell you. Dead! Don't make me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She didn't die then, and nor did my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, the tide is out. A.B. by MAM'S bed, talking to a DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But as the years passed both of them were beginning to fade.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 58.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: As you can appreciate it's difficult to take a history but I'm right in thinking she hasn't been a smoker? A.B. No.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Not been a smoker, doesn't drink, all things considered a very healthy woman. A.B. You think? There is an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: This is a woman who has broken her hip. And of course in someone younger and in better circumstances we would give them antibiotics. At your mother's age and in her state of mind, one wonders if this is altogether kind. A.B. If you don't give her antibiotics what will happen?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: She may recover or not. She could just sleep away. You mustn't reproach yourself. You've done all...more than can be expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. arrives home by cab. MISS SHEPHERD is now wheelchair bound. Her wheelchair has an aerial with a Union Jack pennant. A.B. (to cab driver) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett. Where've you been? A.B. Seeing my mother.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: How is she?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 59. A.B. The same. She doesn't remember me now.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I'm not surprised. She doesn't see you very often. Will you write about me? ALAN BENNETT is in the window, writing. A.B. I don't know (sotto to ALAN BENNETT) She never said this.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I've heard you on the wireless. Does she know that? A.B. How can she? She doesn't know who she is.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: That's what you think. Using your mother. You should be ashamed of yourself. A.B. She didn't say this.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: No, but why shouldn't she?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You write about her all the time, one way or another. You use your mother. A.B. That's what writers do.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Me next, I suppose. Anyway, now you're here I need some shopping done. A.B. You ought to go yourself. You should try and walk more.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I do walk.  139 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 60. A.B. I never see you.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: That's because you're not around in the middle of the night. I want some batteries and some sherbet lemons. Mr Bennett. A.B. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Would you like to push me up the street? A.B. Not particularly, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he does and we see him labouring up the street pushin her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: This'1ll do. Turn me round. Turn me round. A.B. turns the wheelchair round. Now at the top of the sl of the street she pushes herself off with her walking sti and sails down the middle of the street, the expression o her face the nearest it's ever been to pleasure or indeed rapture. It's a real joy ride with A.B. rather alarmed running behind her. When the chair has slowed down, she stops it by slurring slippered feet and when it stops she waves her stick in triumph. It should be a triumphant scene with lots of music. A.B. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I think so. A.B. Would you like me to make you a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: No. I don't want you to go to all that trouble. I'll just have half a cup. Later: she gives the coffee cup back to A.B.  140 141 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 61. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT’D) I have to go to Mass. A.B. You’re not fit.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It’s an anniversary, and a day of obligation. A.B. Who for? A saint?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: No. A young man. A.B. Someone you loved?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Certainly not. Someone I... Someone who died. He would be in his fifties now. A.B. Was he a Catholic?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Possibly. Only he's in purgatory, he needs my prayers. A.B. What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I never bother with names. He wheels her off down the Crescent towards Our Lady of H the RC church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see MISS SHEPHERD at Mass. When she receives the wafer, she struggles out of the wheelchair and prostrates herself so that the long-suffer priest has to bend right down to get it in her mouth whil A.B.
