(who is there with the wheelchair, waiting to wheel back) notices the young man serving at Mass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of the convent. A woman HOUSEKEEPER (not a nun) opens the door.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 62.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: Yes? A.B. I live down the street.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: I've seen you. It's you that has the van. A.B. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: Difficult woman. A.B. A Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: One of the sisters remembers her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. and the HOUSEKEEPER A.B. I've been told she was very argumentative. Is that why she was made to leave?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: Disputatious she was. I've had her pointed out to me on that account. Hankering after the piano. She always thought she was right but she wasn’t right. God is right, end of story. Anyway what do you want to know for? A.B. She's ill.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: Who? The woman? A.B. I wondered if there was a nun available who could talk to her, do her some shopping.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: We don't have shopping nuns. It's a strict order.  143 144 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 63. A.B. I've seen them shopping. I saw one yesterday in Marks and Spencer. She was buying meringues.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: The Bishop may have been coming. A.B. Does he like meringues?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: Who are you, coming round asking if the Bishop like meringues? Are you a communist? A.B. But she's ill. She's a Catholic. I think she may be dying.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: They can pray for her, only you'll have to fill in a form. She'll probably pull her socks up once your back is turned. That's been my experience where invalids are concerned. She leaves the room, heading for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This way out. I don’t want you bumping in to the sisters.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY
dialogues.text: A.B. is coming in at the gate. There are bits of screwed paper on the path. He slips on something. It is plainly s

dialogues.speaker: INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: A.B. walks in with his shoe in his hand. ALAN BENNETT watching. A.B. Another parcel on the path.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: If...when I write about all this, people will say there's too much about shit. A.B. washing his shoe in the sink.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 64.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But there was a lot about shit. Shit was in the forefront. Caring...which is not a word I like...caring is about shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see MISS SHEPHERD in deep conversat with MISS BRISCOE. MISS BRISCOE comes to the front door a rings, A.B. letting her in, MISS SHEPHERD watching resentfully.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: I've talked to Mary. A.B. Or Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Or Margaret. Miss Shepherd anyway. She tells me you don't encourage her to get out and lead a more purposeful life. And put obstacles in her way. A.B. I don't encourage her to think she can become Prime Minister; I do encourage her to try and get to the supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Yes. A carer will often feel that he or she .. A.B. Excuse me. May I stop you? Do not call me the carer. I am not the carer. I hate caring. I hate the thought. I hate the word. I do not care and I do not care for. I am here; she is there. There is no caring.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Alan, I’m sensing hostility again. (pause) You see, I am wondering whether, having cared for Mary as it were single-handed for all these years, you don't, understandably, resent it when the professionals lend a hand.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 65. A.B. No. Though I resent it when the professionals turn up every three months or so and try to tell me what this woman, whom I have coped with on a daily basis for the past fifteen years, is like.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: What is she like? A.B. Mary, as you call her, is a bigoted, blinkered, cantankerous, devious, unforgiving, self-serving, rank, rude, car-mad cow. Which is to say nothing of her flying faeces and her ability to extrude from her withered buttocks turds of such force that they land a yard from the back of the van and their presumed point of exit. Beat. ALAN BENNETT is at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Though of course you didn't say any of that. MISS BRISCOE leaves the study. ALAN BENNETT (CONT ’D) People would think that was because you were too nice, it's actually because you're too timid. A.B. Yes. Though this being England, timid is good too. A.B. goes into the hallway where MISS BRISCOE is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Well this has been very helpful. I'll see about getting her a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (from inside van) Is it a man doctor? A.B. Yes.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 66.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I don't want a man doctor. Don't they have a woman?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd, I only want to take your pulse.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Which hand? Do you have a preference?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: No. MISS SHEPHERD puts her hand through the window.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It's normally cleaner than that.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd. I'd like to take you into hospital for a day or so, just to run some tests.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I've always had great faith in onions.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Yes. Onions can only take you so far, medically speaking. MISS SHEPHERD closes the van window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. and MISS BRISCOE are on the phone. A.B. She won't go into hospital.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: How do you know? A.B. Ask her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Would she go to the day centre? She could be looked at there. And she could stay for a few days A.B. She won't go to the day centre.  148 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 67.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Have you asked her? A.B. She will not go to the day centre. I know.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Of course I'll go. They won’t make me stay in? The back doors of the van are open; MISS SHEPHERD slides herself out on her bottom as MISS BRISCOE confers with an AMBULANCE MAN beside an ambulance parked outside the hous A.B. No. They're going to give you a bath and put you in some clean clothes and do some tests.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Will they leave me to it? A.B. Where?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: In the bath. I know how to bath myself. I’ve won awards for that. A.B. Yes. I remember.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett. A.B. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It won't look as if I'm being taken away will it? A.B. Taken away where?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Where they take people because they're not right. Do they do that still? A.B. Sometimes, but you need a lot of signatures.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 68.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: They pretend things to get you there sometimes. That's the danger with next of kin. It's one of their tricks. They might be pretending it's a day centre. A.B. No.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I've been had like that once before.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Alan.. The AMBULANCE MEN help MISS SHEPHERD out of the van.

dialogues.speaker: AMBULANCE MAN
dialogues.text: Miss Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Now I'm a bit behindhand with things so there may be a bit of Ase

dialogues.speaker: AMBULANCE MAN
dialogues.text: Put your arm around my neck. (she does)

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Oh. I've not gone in for this kind of thing much. The AMBULANCE MEN help her into her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I note how with none of my own distaste the ambulance driver does not hesitate to touch Miss Shepherd and even puts his arm round her as he lowers her into the chair. I note too his careful rearrangement of her greasy clothing, pulling the skirt down over her knees in the interest of modesty.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I'm coming back, you know. This isn’t a toe in the water job.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Is there anything you would like us to take and have us wash?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Why? Most of my things are clean.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 69. NEIGHBOURS watch, PAULINE and RUFUS from the steps opposi as an AMBULANCE MAN wheels her to the ambulance and puts chair on the lift.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: (calling across) Not ill, your friend. A.B. No.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: (hopeful) Not going?

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Only to the Day Centre, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (joining them) The children always ask after her. They used to be so frightened of her when they were young. One of them's in Washington now. The World Bank.

dialogues.speaker: MRS VAUGHAN WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: How long has it been. Ten years?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: More like fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: (together) A lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett. That social worker wanted to know my next of kin. I don't want my next of kin broadcast so I said I didn't have any. Only they're in this envelope. (she gives it him) Keep it under your hat. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT ’D) (to the ambulance driver) I was an ambulance driver myself once, during the war. I knew Kensington in the blackout.

dialogues.speaker: AMBULANCE MAN
dialogues.text: Oh really? The lift rises.  149 150

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The chair goes up on a lift and in this small ascension when she slowly rises above the level of the garden wall there is a vagabond nobility about her, a derelict Nobel prize-winner she looks, her grimy face set in a kind of resigned satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Could we do that again? I'd like another go.

dialogues.speaker: AMBULANCE MAN
dialogues.text: When you come back. MISS SHEPHERD is wheeled into the ambulance. The AMBULANC MEN close the doors. It seems pretty final.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. sits looking at the next of kin envelope. It is mark 'Mr. Bennett, if necessary'. He opens it. On a slip of pa ‘NEXT OF KIN, LEOPOLD GEORGE FAIRCHILD' and a telephone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD is brought into the bathroom by the DAY CEN WORKER and confronted with a full bath of steaming hot wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS SHEPHERD, now clean, wearing a dressing gown, is bro down the corridor by the DAY CENTRE WORKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAY CENTRE WORKER combs MISS SHEPHERD’s newly clean hair ties it back.

dialogues.speaker: DAY CENTRE WORKER
dialogues.text: (to Miss S) There! Your MOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch is being served at the servery. Seven or eight old people are sat at tables eating lunch (mince, potato and peas). Miss SHEPHERD, now in clean clothes, is sitting al at one table. The DAY CENTRE WORKER brings her lunch to h  151 152 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 71. A WOMAN comes and sits at MISS SHEPHERD’S table.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Hello Margaret. MISS SHEPHERD looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. arriving at MR FAIRCHILD'S bungalow in a local taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR FAIRCHILD, his wife EDITH and A.B. having tea.

dialogues.speaker: MR FAIRCHILD
dialogues.text: Fourteen years? You must be a saint. Difficult woman, my sister. Edith won't have her in the house. EDITH smiles wanly. A.B. No, I'm not a saint. Just lazy. I know she was an ambulance driver.

dialogues.speaker: MR FAIRCHILD
dialogues.text: Yes. And a nun. Twice over. ‘til they got rid of her. She spent some time in an an asylum. Banstead. Which was my fault

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MR FAIRCHILD
dialogues.text: Mind you, she was a difficult woman. And such a bully. A.B. Did she bully you? She bullies me.

dialogues.speaker: MR FAIRCHILD
dialogues.text: I had her put away. Incarcerated. Sectioned, is what you call it today. Mind you she got away from them too. Gave them the slip. Does she still play? The piano. A.B. No.  153

dialogues.speaker: 155A
dialogues.text: 156 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 72.

dialogues.speaker: MR FAIRCHILD
dialogues.text: That is sad. Have you heard of Cortot? Alfred Cortot, the virtuoso pianist. A.B. Yes.. He gets up and goes to the cabinet, finds a record.

dialogues.speaker: MR FAIRCHILD
dialogues.text: Margaret was his pupil. She had to go over to Paris for lessons. Wasn’t easy in those days. And practiced. Oh my word she used to practice all day long. Only the nuns put a stop to that. I was a vet in Africa and when I came back the music was out. Finished. Practicing had become praying. He drops the needle on the record. MR FAIRCHILD (CONT’D) Played at the Proms once. The record plays. They listen. The music takes us back to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 1938 concert from the title sequence, which we see ag The camera moves in on the pianist, and we see that she i the young MISS SHEPHERD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As MISS SHEPHERD is crossing the reception room, dark exc for a single night light, she sees a piano. She stops, dr to it in spite of herself. She goes to it, opens it. Her arthritic but newly clean hands touch the keyboard. She tentatively plays the first bars of the slow movement, fu of mistakes. Stops. Tries again. Stops. Then, as if the memory is in her muscles, her fingers mov across the keys and she plays an an elaborately beautiful passage from the middle of the movement, almost to perfection. The music takes her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music continues to play. A.B. walks up the drive, carrying a bunch of flowers, and passes the van. A.B. taps on van door.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 73. A.B. Miss Shepherd? Miss Shepherd? He opens the van door.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just tried to visit you.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I wasn't stopping there. A woman said my face rang a bell. Was I ever in Banstead? And would not stop. They gave me some mince. She said, you'll find the mince here a step up from the mince in Banstead. I don't know about the mince in Banstead, or anywhere else for that matter. It's where they put people when they’re not right. A.B. Well you look nice and clean.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: That will be the bath. They let me do it myself, only the nurse came and gave me some finishing touches. She said I'd come up a treat. A.B. offers her the bunch a flowers. Pause. A.B. I bought you these.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Flowers? What do I want with flowers? They only die. I've got enough on my plate without flowers... A.B. You won't often have been given flowers.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Who says? I've had bigger flowers than these and with ribbons on. These don't compare. (pause) Music. How are people supposed to avoid it? You see I had it at my fingertips. I had it in my bones. I could play in the dark, had to sometimes. And the keys were like rooms. C Major. D Minor. Dark rooms. Light rooms. It was like a mansion to me, music.  157

dialogues.speaker: THE LADY IN THE VAN
dialogues.text: Pause. He does.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only it worried me that playing came easier than praying. And I said this, which may have been a error. A.B. Said it to whom?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: My confessor. He said that was another vent the devil could creep through. So he outlawed the piano. Put paid to music generally. Said that dividends would accrue in terms of growth of the spirit. Which they did. They did. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT ’D) How is your mother? A.B. The same.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Still in the coma? A.B. No.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Just getting a bit of shut-eye. People do. A.B. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Mr Bennett. Hold my hand. It's clean. 74. Closes the van door and walks towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some of what this woman had been I found out after she died, so with her life a deliberate mystery...

dialogues.speaker: INT. 23 GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY
dialogues.text: A.B. at the window.

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: lies THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 75.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «..to tell it I have occasionally had to invent, though much of it one could not make up. And I do not make it up when I say that it was on the morning after this talk, when she lay in the van with clean clothes and with her hair washed, that on that same morning comes the social worker in to the garden, bearing clean clothes, linen and ointment and knocks on the door of the van.

dialogues.speaker: GLOUCESTER CRESCENT. DAY 158/159
dialogues.text: BRISCOE at the van door.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRISCOE
dialogues.text: Mary (She knocks on van) Mary? and Alan Bennett watch from inside. She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: GLOUCESTER CRESCENT, DAY 160
dialogues.text: arrives at the van door with MISS BRISCOE. MISS SHEPHERD dead inside.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It is a van no longer. It is a sepulchre. Even now I do not venture into this evil-smelling tomb. I feel cheated that the discovery of the body has not actually been mine and that, having observed so much for so long, I am not the first to witness her death. Now in quick succession come the doctor, the priest and men from the undertaker's, all of whom this cold winter morning do what no one else has done for twenty years: namely without pause and seemingly without distaste step inside the van. We see the undertakers men take out the body in an ordina seeming box.  163 THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral. The coffin is in front of the altar. The FAIRCHILDS in the front pew. The NEIGHBOURS behind.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Lord, grant her ever-lasting rest and let perpetual light shine upon her. Present her to God the most high. As the priest continues, a man materialises behind A.B. I UNDERWOOD, MISS SHEPHERD's visitor.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: (quietly) She's gone then, the lady. (indicating the priest) He would know. She'll have told him. Only they got to keep mum, vicars. No helping the police with their enquiries. Did you know she was on the run? A.B. Miss Shepherd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashback. The junction. The motorbike slams into the van The YOUNG BIKER's face smashes into the windscreen. The Y BIKER dead on the road. MISS SHEPHERD at his side. She ge back into the van and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Miss whatever you called her. Oh yes. Stationary at a junction a young lad on a motorbike comes round a corener too fast. Smashes in to her vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: Not her fault. Only here's a dead boy on the road, whom she thinks she’s killed. Does she call the police? Flag down a fellow motorist? Oh no. She clears off pronto, thereby putting herself on the wrong side of the law. A.B. So you blackmailed her?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 77.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWOOD
dialogues.text: I am a policeman, Mr Bennett. Retired of course, but we don't do things like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin is slid into the hearse.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Well, it's a cut above her previous vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All those years stood on my doorstep she was outside the law. A life...this is what I keep thinking...a life beside which mine is just dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. is alone at the grave. The undertaker's men hover nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Left to my own thoughts at the graveside, one of the undertaker’s men takes my eye. Not an occupation one drifts into, I imagine...

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: (who materialises behind him) Mr Bennett, excuse me, I'm supposed to be the centrepiece here.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I’m forgetting that the dead know everything.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: You should be fighting back the tears, not eyeing up the talent. A.B. turns startled to ALAN BENNETT who is beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Well, it's a thought. She's dead now. I can do what I want with her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Yes you can, I'm dead. Feel free. Oh, hello. There are two of you now. Is that because you're in two minds?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 78.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Yes. A.B. No. MISS SHEPHERD walks away from the grave, the other two catching up with her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I've been wondering. Would either of you object if the van were to become a place of pilgrimage.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: No. A.B. I'm getting rid of the van. The van is going.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Healing could take place and any proceeds could go towards the nuns. A.B. The nuns! What did the nuns ever do for you?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Well not much, but when the donations start rolling in they'll realise what a catch I would have been. It was the same with St Bernadette. They didn’t realise with her until it was too late. This way! There's someone I want you to meet! MISS SHEPHERD turns off the path, looking for someone. Th follow. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT’D) (To ALAN BENNETT) That's something you could do. This thing you're trying to write, you could pump it up a bit. If it were along the lines of The Song of Bernadette it would make you a packet. ALAN BENNETT looks unconvinced. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT ’D) Why do you just let me die? I'd like to go up into heaven. An ascension, possibly. A transfiguration.  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 79.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: That's not really my kind of thing. She has found who she's been looking for: a beaming YOUNG BIKER, sitting behind a gravestone, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: There you are. This is my new friend. It's the young man who crashed into the van.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BIKER
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I thought it was me that killed him, only it turns out it was his own fault, so one way and another we've got heaps to talk about. Well, goodbye She laughs. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT’D) Mr Bennett...

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: I came in to your drive for three months and I stayed for fifteen years! She continues to laugh. MISS SHEPHERD (CONT’D) Mr Bennett

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: Do you know what that is?

dialogues.speaker: A.B.
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SHEPHERD
dialogues.text: It's the last laugh. She takes the BIKER'S hand. They walk away. A.B. looks at ALAN BENNETT. ALAN BENNETT shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Well, she wanted an ascension. Let's answer her prayers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stand by, Miss Mary Teresa Shepherd, late of 23 Gloucester Crescent. Up you go! They look back towards MISS SHEPHERD who ascends to Heave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. cleaning out the van.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: Starting out as someone incidental to my life...she remained on the edge of it so long she became not incidental to it at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This speech over various shots including A.B. sitting wit his mother, who lives on, on a bench overlooking the empt bay at Weston-super-Mare; and A.B. sitting by her bedside

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As homebound sons and daughters looking after their parents think of it as just marking time before their lives start..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, A.B. is clearing the garden of Miss Shepherd’s pla bags. The outline of the truck visible in flecks of yello paint. ALAN BENNETT is at the desk in the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --So like them I learned there is no such thing as marking time, and that time marks you. In accommodating her and accommodating to her, I find twenty years of my life has gone. The van is hauled out of the drive by a salvage truck. Th truck driver scrawls 'On Tow' in the dirt on the windscre A.B. watches it go.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This broken-down old woman, her delusions, and the slow abridgement of her life with all its vehicular permutations, these have been given to me to record.. . (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .»-as others record journeys across Tibet or Patagonia or the thighs of a dozen women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.B. opens a box containing copies of the first LRB paper edition of The Lady In The Van. A.B. You wanted me to make things happen and I never have much. But it doesn't matter, because what I've learned - and maybe she taught me - is that you don't put yourself into what you write. You find yourself there.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: I never wanted to write about her. And if there'd been a bit more in your life, I wouldn't have had to. A.B. Maybe I will now. The sound of the key in the front door, which bangs shut. voice calls 'Hi!'

dialogues.speaker: ALAN BENNETT
dialogues.text: What? A.B. Have a bit more in my life. I might even start living. A.B. looks towards the MAN who now comes through the stud door and greets him, and who seems quite at home.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good day?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Not bad. You? A.B. shrugs and the ATTRACTIVE MAN puts his hand on his shoulder and leaves it there. He goes towards the kitchen stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You coming down?  THE LADY IN THE VAN - FINAL SCREENPLAY 82. A.B. Alright. A.B. following him, saying to ALAN BENNETT as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: A.B., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the end of the story, it might make a play. What do you think? ALAN BENNETT still at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (Going downstairs) Now I’m here I think you should stop talking to yourself. A.B. looks back at the desk, and the chair is empty. A.B. smiles and follows ATTRACTIVE MAN downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide on Gloucester Crescent, we see the real Alan Bennett cycling down the road. In the now empty garden, A.B. and the neighbours conduct small ceremony to mark the unveiling of a blue plaque on wall. With them, a film crew gathered outside 23 Gloucester Crescent making the film. A.B. Gloucester Crescent has had many notable residents but none odder or more remarkable than Miss Mary Shepherd to whom we dedicate this blue plaque today. The plaque reads: Miss M T Shepherd “The Lady in the Van" Lived here 1974-1989

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — FINAL SCREENPLAY 83.
